Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 10:38AM Carlatap wrote: Spark, I'm so sorry you are going through such a terrible time. I agree with everthing that has been said above, but I just want to add one thing.... Drink water, drink water, drink water. This helps the chemo to get out of your system quicker and then it doesn't remain in your stomach, or mouth for as long. And you won't get so constipated. Hang in there!  This is definately a life changing journey. "Be strong and courageous"
Posts.Title: Help! Just started DD AC/T for Triple Negative spark rcca

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 06:35PM Carlatap wrote: Hi Disneyfan, I believe its very smart of you to get an ultra sound. If any of the lumps look suspicious, the radiologist will probably want to schedule a biopsi. If they look like they are full of fluid, they will say they are probably cysts. To be on the safe side, I would ask for biopsies, especially if any of your family has had cancer. When I went in for mammogram and knew I had a lump, I was told they wanted me to have an ultra sound that same morning. After the ultra sound, they wanted to order a biopsi. They wanted me to come in on another day-I told them I would really appreciate if they could do it that same afternoon. They fit it in to their schedule. Don't be afraid to ask questions, and to speak up for yourself. Do you have someone going with you? I would encourage that as well. I really hope they are cysts-even though I was diagnosed with cancer, my daughter has gone in twice for lumps, and they have been cysts. So, don't think the worst. Please let us know how it goes. Wish you the best, Carla
Posts.Title: Lumps, Lumps and more Lumps disneyfan78 disneyfan78

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2014 04:22PM Carlatap wrote: hi Dee, very interedting question. I have the BRCA2 mutation, had double mastectomy, and oomph and am post menopausal and i am 55. I have found a lump which shows up as a cyst on the ultra sound. I have been taking paxil for over 6 months. I would be interested knowing any info as well.
